thread.title: It's the emergency spillway, not the Oroville Dam that has a hole in it
thread.title_full: It's the emergency spillway, not the Oroville Dam that has a hole in it

author: Matt Hamilton
title: It's the emergency spillway, not the Oroville Dam that has a hole in it
text:
Live updates: Evacuations ordered below Oroville Dam Feb. 12, 2017, 7:56 p.m. 
"This is not a Drill. Repeat this is not a drill,” the National Weather Service said Sunday, urging people living below Oroville Dam to evacuate. The evacuation was ordered because of a “hazardous situation” involving the Northern California dam's emergency spillway. The National Weather Service said the auxiliary spillway is expected to fail and could send an “uncontrolled release of flood waters from Lake Oroville.” Feb. 12, 2017, 7:51 p.m. Oroville Dam not threatened, it's the dam's emergency spillway Matt Hamilton Water cascades down the spillway below the Oroville dam. (David Butow / For the Times) 
Officials emphasized that while erosion had carved a massive hole in the Oroville Dam's main spillway, the dam itself is structurally sound. 
“Believe me, in the last several days there have been a lot of eyes on it,” said Bill Croyle, acting director of the California Department of Water Resources. “Oroville Dam is not in any way a part of the damage that occurred.” 
Officials have estimated it could cost $100 million to $200 million to repair the damage to the spillway and other features. Latest updates
